title: Will President Donald Trump and President Xi Jinping sign a trade agreement before 1 January 2020?
preds: updating forecast for passage of time.

The Phase 1 trade deal between the US and China that was announced at the end of last week comes later than I expected. This most likely means shifting a signing date over the year into january as documents need to be drafted and Xmas is coming soon.

Lightheader says the signing will be in January.  Unless of course somebody is able to explain to The Leader Of The Free World that he's been had once again, impelling him to back out once again from an almost-agreed deal.  But not this year, anyway.

Calling this one based on WSJ article that Lighthizer and Lou He are meeting to sign the deal in early January.  https://www.wsj.com/articles/us-china-confirm-reaching-phase-one-trade-deal-11576234325?emailToken=bbb8f88146bb5c47a9b7a4095bf2718av1loMO8i5fg4tQzgpr1Wb/q2IIT0+gX4HTfCIb53cdlLgPuO6hBEB25XBsr6WujppmD5OD9jtWf2sHUiFYt2azmAbN4ern/s9zVM5/5OVgY%3D&reflink=article_copyURL_share
Nothing signed yet. China "signing" the "deal" after Trump ïmpeachment could be interpreted by some journos and spinners as Beiing's tenuous support for US democratic process and Constitution.
Ok, hattip to @Chrisp for setting me straight on how to view the "agreement" currently in place. I'll go back to my pessimistic scoring for this forecast.

Reducing further.  It only takes ambassador-level officials to sign this deal. The remaining steps include finalization of the legal text and translation. On the one hand it seems quite feasible by the end of the year. Additionally, Trump would probably prefer to have it signed before Christmas for PR reasons. However, admin officials suggest the signing will take place in January [1].  [1] https://www.wsj.com/articles/us-china-confirm-reaching-phase-one-trade-deal-11576234325?mod=hp_lead_pos1
I still have doubts, but I'll go with the news and expect another shoe to drop.

Xi may be listening to Deep State thinking CHINA can last 6 yrs w/o giving in to the Orange man. But would Trump be to far off to think that over the next 6 years, at this rate , that CHINA will question the vision of Xi and un chair him? This makes a deal possible. f Xi is going to compromise he will do it now before he has spent his goodwill.
https://www.nbcnews.com/business/economy/trump-confirms-u-s-china-have-reached-agreement-trade-deal-n1100876?fbclid=IwAR2kBjjg-L2Otg9z-y86eGU2SMpDGvlzEp0_fDPEySEFx_kgKOPONkm_fUU

There was some news this morning about a "Phase One" trade agreement, and a "Phase Two" was pending so I raised my estimate quite a bit.  However,  the key word in the question seems to be "sign."   That is, the agreement must be written, no matter how significant the trade agreement might be.   This agreement does not seem to do a lot.  It eliminates US tariffs and Chinese counter tariffs set to go into effect this Sunday, the Chinese agree to buy some agricultural products, there are some intellectual property concessions by the Chinese (they will no longer demand US companies give up their intellectual property to do business in China) and there are some financial services clauses.   The agreement cannot be "inked" until it passes some "legal hurdles" in the US per CNBC.  A few democrats denounced the agreement while the Republics, so far, have been silent. Thus, it is a long way from a trade deal 1) in writing that 2) the two presidents can sign.

After Friday’s announcements a Phase one deal is agreed, but needs to go through proceedings before signing (https://www.theguardian.com/business/2019/dec/13/china-confirms-phase-one-trade-deal-us-tariffs?CMP=Share_iOSApp_Other). Therefore no signature before Jan 1

Backing off a little for now because I am concerned about timing. WSJ: "Phase One Agreement Needs to Go through Legal Procedures in Both Countries before Getting Signed, Chinese Commerce Vice Minister" EDIT: Key question now is what needs to happen before Trump and Xi can sign the agreement.  Importantly, I don't think legislatures need to be involved. Ratification typically takes place after a deal is signed (comparison class - USMCA, other international agreements - e.g. the Paris Agreement on Climate Change). So what else needs to be done before the deal can be inked? CNBC reported that there was a text of the deal that China and US have reportedly agreed. However, I am guessing this text is relatively general (specific enough for Trump and Xi to know what they are agreeing to but not detailed enough to represent a legal document) There is probably additional legal language that would have to be there.  Perhaps there are other steps too. I will need to do more research.
Press conference by China iin 20 mins is an encouraging sign. However they might just say we have made progress. Markets are on edge.
From NYT: “The text of the agreement has not been finished and it is unclear whether China has agreed to all of the details included in the plan.”
Feels like we have been here before. No news out of China on a deal yet.

Swanson, Rappeport and Bradsher (2019) Dec. 12, stated that: WASHINGTON — The United States has settled on final terms of a partial trade deal with China, several people familiar with the negotiations said, a development that could ease tensions between the world’s largest economies just days before the long-running trade war is set to escalate. President Trump met with his top economic advisers Thursday afternoon at the White House, where the president agreed to significant reductions on tariffs he has placed on $360 billion of Chinese goods in return for China’s commitment to purchase American farm products and make other concessions, the people said. As part of the agreement, the president is expected to announce that he will delay or cancel tariffs on $160 billion of consumer products from China that are scheduled to go into effect on Sunday. Those additional tariffs would have resulted in the United States taxing nearly everything China ships into the United States and foregoing them would prevent another escalation in a trade fight that has inflicted economic damage on both sides of the Pacific (Para. 1-3).
*
Reference
* Swanson, A., Rappeport A. & Bradsher, K. (2019). U.S. Settles on Outline of Elusive Trade Deal. The New York Times. Economy. Dec. 12, 2019
https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/12/business/economy/trump-china-trade-deal.html

Some reported possibilities re signing of proposed 'phase one' deal:  "Under one scenario, Robert E. Lighthizer, the president’s chief trade negotiator, and Chinese Ambassador to the U.S. Cui Tiankai could sign the document as soon as tomorrow. Alternatively, Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin could travel to Beijing for the signing." Source: https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2019/12/12/trump-says-trade-deal-with-china-is-very-close-just-days-ahead-tariff-deadline/

Trade deal announced. The question now for the most part is whether it will be formally signed on time. It doesn’t seem very likely that signing it will take more than 3 weeks. https://www.politico.com/news/2019/12/12/us-and-china-reach-partial-trade-deal-084028

Bloomberg reporting a "preliminary agreement" deal citing sources. But much of what is in "the agreement"  has been discussed ad infinitum over the past several months. The question more relevent to this problem is whether what Bloomberg is leaking really constitute a "trade agreement of some sort."
Sounds like a deal is imminent, what constitutes “sign” is another question. Time table is tight, but the situation has evolved rapidly
No, I believe the negotiations are being used as a means to manipulate the stock market for gain.
Increasing from 2% on Trump's latest comment that a deal is close.

Signing not totally impossible by year-end, IMO: 
https://www.cnbc.com/2019/12/11/us-china-trade-deal-will-happen-before-dec-15-tariffs-analysts-say.html
Bringing my forecast in line with the crowd.
The delay of the implementation of the December 15th tariffs significantly reduce (in fact totally eliminate) the need for a meeting at this stage.

POTUS will be focused on impeachment, and with only a week left for holiday shopping remaining, it makes little sense for Trump to budge now in order to boost confidence. Any such move would have made sense a month ago to spike confidence. It also doesn't make sense for China to make a move with the Democratic primary a few months away. They might as well wait and see if they'd be better off waiting for a potential change in power, depending on who the challenger is.

The 15 Dec tariffs are being delayed reportedly according to WSJ sources. While that is a positive sign as far as a phase 1 deal is concerned I see it as a negative sign as far as timing is concerned. If signing a deal was likely to happen in the next couple of weeks, the tariffs would have probably been revised rather than simply delayed. The delay shows that the two sides want more space to continue talking, which lays some groundwork for a phase 1 to happen after the New Year if ever.
Dropping a few points to zero because there's only a few weeks left in the year and I don't see an opportunity to sign an agreement like at an APEC summit.

It is in Trumps interest for election purposes. So long as it looks like some ground has been given by China, a deal will benefit Trump in terms of his personal standing as well as give a good boost to the economy. For China, with the goings on in Hong Kong and economic issues starting to bite, they might find it easier to just give a few easy wins to Trump now rather than have to wait until another year or more (after US elections) when they may not even get a better deal from whoever replaces him.

I don't really care if they do. We'll subsidize the farmers and everybody hurt with the tariffs. Ole China  ain't looking too good. Keep it up and we'll reallocate that reserve to our coffers soon enough...
Double what the Reuter's polled analysts said would happen in Nov.
https://www.google.com/amp/s/amp.scmp.com/economy/china-economy/article/3041067/chinas-foreign-exchange-reserves-fall-us9-billion-november "The dollar, meanwhile, rose about 1 per cent against a basket of other major currencies last month."

Trump has declared that any deal  "would have to be weighted to favor the United States ", while Xi Jinping wants a deal only "on the basis of mutual respect and equality" (1). The trade war is not desired by china, but they will be ready to fight back until an equal deal is achieved. On the NATO summit, trump said: "I like the idea of waiting until after the election for the China deal, but they want to make a deal now and we’ll see whether or not the deal is going to be right, its gotta be right", "It’s not if they want to make it, it’s if I want to make it, and we’ll see what happens" (2). However, there is no clear signs of anything happening soon on this regard. Also, we cant forget the tension between USA and China on other topics such as the Uygur minorities, the Taiwan Straits and the Hong Kong protests (3), which does not help in the negotiations.  1-. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trade-china/chinas-xi-says-he-wants-to-work-out-initial-trade-deal-with-us-idUSKBN1XW0FP
2-. https://www.scmp.com/economy/china-economy/article/3040426/donald-trump-no-deadline-trade-war-deal-china-may-come-after
3-. http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1172533.shtml
Trump has recently flip-flopped as to progress but unlikely he’ll risk political fall-out from rising prices or delaying yet again.
Trade deals take a long time to negotiate

China can afford to play the long game as they are not at the mercy of election cycles and would therefore be happy to wait to see if Trump loses in 2020. Trump woul d therefore be offered only a very "bad" deal which he would be reluctant to take after saying that Trade Wars are easy to win.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trade-china-kushner/jared-kushner-trumps-son-in-law-takes-bigger-role-in-china-trade-talks-idUSKBN1Y80IA The Leader of the Free World's jared-of-all-trades is pitching in to get it sorted.   Swell.  Lots of us like our sons-in-law, but offhand I can't think of anybody else who actually worships one.  I suppose this religion one would be called "gamprolatry," depending on my very hazy recollection of Greek, with The Current Incumbent the only known practitioner.
Trump today announced he is willing to wait until after the election. While he may be being dishonest this lack of goodwill lowers the likelihood slightly.

Who knows? Trump may be bluffing, but lowering forecast further per his comment today about 'no rush to complete a deal':
https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/03/business/economy/trump-china-trade.html

There is not much to be gained by waiting much longer. The main reason ist to Prevent China from becoming the world´s number one in economics, and to try to achieve that leaves only a limited number of possibilities, almost all of which are already being tried. The Closer the reelection Campaign, the more likely it is, that this Topic will be settled, temporarily at least.
Coming down. There would have to have been more progress by now to make a deal this month even somewhat likely.

Will President Donald Trump and President Xi Jinping sign a trade agreement before 1 January 2020?
I am cuttin g my forecast by 100%, 30 days to go and not a peep. I agree with @jayb that HK legislation was a stick in the eye.

I don't look for Trump to make any huge policy strides forward during the holiday season.  Consumers have already weathered Black Friday and are heading to Cyber Monday with no resolution.  What would be his motivation to resolve things now?
No information leads me to believe that this will occur

With the Rajapaska family now back in power in Sri Lanka the highly touted port deal at Hambantota Beijing cut with the previous Lankan administration- so vital to China's "Belt and Road" initiative- could be put on "go slow"...  and if you surf over to Infolanka dot com you will notice signals that India is showing real money to the Rajipaskas. Bloomberg today 29Nov reports that the Rajapaskas want to nix the deal completely.  In the calculus predicting this problem before 1 Jan 2020, this information- in a non-scientific way-  factors in on the side of more circumspection on the part of Beijng to sign a "trade agreement" with presidente Trump.
U.S. signing Hong Kong legislation that China gov't opposes may reduce chances (for this year). https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/27/us/politics/trump-hong-kong.html
Will distract from the impeachment news

Revising dramatically upward from 7% to 25% given recent news. I was sure that the pending Hong Kong legislation would doom a phase one agreement, but that doesn't seem to have happened and the negotiations seem to be moving ahead. "A preliminary trade deal between the United States and China is "millimeters away," a senior administration official said on Wednesday...The comments add to the growing optimism that the U.S. and China can announce a so-called phase one agreement soon after the Thanksgiving holiday weekend." [1]  "China on Thursday attacked the United States after President Donald Trump signed the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act,
calling it a “blatant hegemonic move”, but observers said Beijing was unlikely to retaliate in a way that would undermine the ongoing trade talks." [2] [1] https://www.politico.com/news/2019/11/27/us-trade-deal-china-074230
[2] https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3039769/official-millimetres-separate-us-china-phase-one-trade-deal
Adjusting down based on Trump signing bill supporting Hong Kong. Though I think we will get a Phase 1 deal, I think it will come in January
If the impeachment inquiry starts to take a turn for the president I could see him signing a trade deal just to change the narrative, regardless of whether it is a good deal for the country or not.
Time is running out on trade discussions
Increasing probability on reports that the US and China have reached consensus on solving issues around trade after Phone call between Liu He, Lighthizer and Mnuchin.
Raising from 13 on China’s IP concession.
The time frame is too short for two reasons: both parties have reason to delay, and Trump would find doing it after the new year better showmanship.

Both Trump and Xi Jinping need a deal (weakening economy + problems at home (Impeachment & Hong Kong)). In the last few weeks both parties slowly give in towards a Phase I deal. This weekend's news that China will raise penalties on IP theft is another sign. Although the window until the end of the year is rather short I still believe the chance of a deal getting signed is the toss of a coin.
Revising upward slightly given yesterday's news: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trade-china/trump-xi-send-positive-signals-on-initial-deal-to-defuse-us-china-trade-war-idUSKBN1XW0FP
We have one party lowering expectations whie the other raises expectations to maximize disappointment and earn pr points off the failure It'll be closer to the Chinese new year.

Both the Chinese and US economies are slowing (or are not as buoyant as when the trade war started). Since "it's about the economy, stupid", I think they may manage to sign the tiniest of deals to roll back the more destructive tariffs coming in December which will damage the US economy and the likelihood of a Trump reelection. The longer Trump waits the more it gets caught into the reelection debate. It's a tight window which is why I am ascribing a 1/10 chance of a deal.

Media coverage looking at the "two sides" moving closer to agreeing on one (1) thing, this or that company, one trade issue. That is not a "trade agreement." What constitutes what you call a "trade agreement of some sort" anyhow. Some folks who lord over the Wikipedia guidelines might even categorize "trade agreement of some sort" as "weasel words."
Increasing from 11% on Trump statement that a deal is close.
Not going to happen. Motivation in this area is lackluster at best.

Tiny bump up due to attempt to schedule new trade talks. Neither side seems too willing to budge on demands. U.S. action in Hong Kong may complicate matters. Though it may hurt U.S. retail sector during the holiday season, past actions suggest to me Trump is willing to stick it out for better terms.
Some experts close to the White house just claimed that the signing of the phase one deal may slide into next year.

Will President Donald Trump and President Xi Jinping sign a trade agreement before 1 January 2020? 
Cutting my forecast by a third. I just don't see a motivation for either side to make this happen in the time allowed.

China will wait it out.

Reducing 2% on the Hong Kong bill, which will anger China and put Trump in a weaker negotiating position, which could lead him to conclude that phase 1 at this stage is not worth it because he wouldn’t get a good enough deal.

Reducing due to the impact of the Senate bill on Hong Kong. China seems pretty upset about the US response and Pence himself said this could make a trade deal challenging. Rhetoric always spikes as the Trump administration nears a deal, so I’m not ready to call this yet

probably something, will be signed, but not very significant.

I don't think this is likely. With a policy based question any analysis is difficult because the true incentives and intentions of the governments are difficult to parse. Are we to trust that the current exclusion is through 1/31/2020? As always, the outside view- The time window is short. We're about 490 days in to talks- what's another 42 days?  The media is focusing on the impeachment through x-mas.  https://www.china-briefing.com/news/the-us-china-trade-war-a-timeline/
the closest think to a trade deal these two are going to come to is If DT offers Xi free accommodations for Life at Trump Tower, Istanbul.

Trump has a difficult task.  He must make his isolationist supporters happy--the same ones who insisted he pull out of the Transpacific trade pack--and the farmers who are facing the rising level of farm bankruptcies.  Right now, the farmers seem to be okay with the subsidies substituting for their lost profits.  In fact, I saw something on TV (do not remember which new show CNBC?) where a farm reporter state that farmers believe they will always get a check--either from consumers or the government--due to their political power at the national level.

Recent trade talks point to a desire, by both sides,  to reach a win-win agreement soon.  However, China now possesses a fleeting advantage - one of "time". This is evident in China's latest request for the US to reverse all Trump tariffs. As 'time" can be a fleeting advantage, it is unclear how long they intend to wield it. What's clear, though, is the current US administration's need for a win in this space; since the 2020 election is close at hand and as the US president's impeachment investigation picks up steam.
Tariffs hurt US more than they hurt China.

Coming down from 19%. China seems to want phase 1 to be a minor deal and it is possible Trump wouldn’t accept anything until further concessions are offered. https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3038056/us-china-interim-trade-deal-hamstrung-fundamental-differences

I think the feedback loop between markets, the Fed, and Trump is deteriorating given less appetite in the Fed for continued cuts and market expectations for a deal. This makes a serious market reaction to no deal more likely and puts the Trump administration in a bad position that the Fed (based on committee rhetoric) is less likely to bail them out of.  https://seekingalpha.com/article/4307259 Small adjustment given:
- anything could happen on the trade front
- a negative reaction to no deal may force the Feds hand
- scope concerns, would the market tolerate kicking the can into 2020?

Major factors I am considering:
- the US and China have previously appeared close to a deal on multiple occasions only for negotiations to fail
- However, the bar for a phase 1 deal is relatively low
- Trump needs a win, which means he is willing to take a deal even if it's not ideal. From this lens, his latest comments are not indicative of an unbridgeable divide but instead can be viewed as part of Trump's messaging campaign to the American public. He benefits from appearing to be strong arming the Chinese.
- For China, poor economic data is showcasing they are struggling from the trade war and while the leadership is probably willing to wait out until after the 2020 election before engaging with the US on a major deal, it could very well be willing to take a step toward a deal in with a phase 1 agreement to improve/stabilize business sentiment in the short term.
- Timing is short, reducing the likelihood Overall, considering these factors I find it difficult to go very low (consensus currently at 10%). References
https://www.cnbc.com/2019/11/14/chinas-economy-grinds-lower-as-october-indicators-miss-forecasts.html
https://www.theguardian.com/business/2019/nov/14/chinese-manufacturing-trade-war-us
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trade-china-kudlow/u-s-getting-close-to-trade-deal-with-china-white-house-economic-adviser-idUSKBN1XO33Q
https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2019/11/14/business/ap-as-china-us-trade.html

Despite the strong trending language out of China and the US since October 7th, there still seems to be a lot of slippage in setting a date and nailing down the exact terms. This makes me hesitant to forecast a better than 50% chance of yes. By the same token, both Xi and Trump are under pressure to show stronger economic performance (for example Xi - Pork prices, Trump - Election) which makes me hesitant to forecast a better than 50% chance of no. The main variable I am watching is progress on the Xi/Trump meeting which can only have one purpose, signing a trade agreement and will be adjusting forecasts based on that.
Both sides have an incentive to reach an agreement but I think that is unlikely given how many times I have heard both sides are close only to see things fall apart.

China will draw this out and seek the upper hand as long as possible. They have other markets that are just as lucrative and can outlast any attempts trump makes to get what he seeks. Some trade agreements msy be made but they will be minor ones that benefit china more than US.

United stated of America under Donald Trump will not hit a trade deal until china agrees on some geopolitical terms. Starting with the south china sea corridor, which is believed to have large amounts of oil and mineral beneath the surface of the seabed. Everything is about oil, OIl is the commodity that is the second biggest player in the world of capitalism after gold. Now, if China could gain control and start pumping oil without the united states is something they won't be very pleased with. The US Oil limited are collectively manufacturing more than 13.1 million barrels every day just behind is Russian corporation with 12 million a day, far more than china's output of 3.8 million barrels a day. There is a lot of conversations of a trade deal being struck anytime soon which is coming from the past 3 years, and it is not gonna happen anytime soon either. This year marked some of the greatest highs in the market and also Aramco going public with a valuation between $1.5T - $1.8T very nice, But have you also seen a row of failing IPO like uber and we work, And all of the unrest in the middle- east and eastern Europe. This is not how so much of thing could end with just a deal, this kind of behavior have caused some kind of harm in the history which is the main reason why all of these things are happening today, In the past, we are living thinking to a make future? Just think more than yourself once and find yourself within you, not in materialistic things like money,
Important for Trump to end the conflict and create a win.
I think both want to move ASAP
Will President Donald Trump and President Xi Jinping sign a trade agreement before 1 January 2020? Each day that passes makes this seem more remote.
Resolve a long-standing trade war in under 2 months with all the impeachment stuff going on?  Heck no.

- Phase I agreed upon in October, stated 3 - 4 weeks to finalize Phase II (some assumption this will then happen)
- US exports to China down, we will want to favorably support those industries impacted before the end of the year (such as soybean farmers who are now entering harvest time)
- Will not want US consumers impacted by higher tariffs on goods at height of holiday shopping season
- China economy worst in years, will feel pressure to agree to trade deal for their own benefit
- Leaving opening for Phase II breakdown, not enough time, continued political posturing on either side

Need some time to do more research, but my early observations are:
- tariffs remain the Trump administrations best leverage (both against China and the Fed)
- continued uncertainty will hurt manufacturing output, raw materials, and workers in the US
- US economy is still strong on a comparative basis though new tariffs targeting consumer products will hurt more than recent rounds
-Structural issue remain between both sides I think there is more than a 5% chance of a deal (current consensus), but past experiences and recent comments increase my skepticism. Like I said at beginning - more research needed, but I’ll say 25% for now

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trade-china/trump-says-has-not-agreed-to-roll-back-tariffs-on-chinese-goods-idUSKBN1XI1TQ A few days ago, I would have said sure, but once again The Leader Of The Free World humiliates both his own team and the other one.  If I were Xi and his folks (and I'm not), I don't think we'd bother with this character any more until after the election.  If he wins, we can go another couple of rounds, although without much hope of anything coming of it.   If he loses, we might not get a better deal from the new kids, but at least we'd get one that wouldn't be repudiated before the ink is wet.   I have entirely lost confidence in any national leader who really believes it worthwhile to negotiate anything with the US just now.  Everyone--well, almost everyone--has to pretend to take us seriously enough to sit around the table without smirking while talks proceed, and maybe even to sign whatever comes out of the sessions.  But if they don't know how evanescent any such agreement is these days, I am afraid I feel contempt rather than pity for them.   Mutatis mutandis, that goes for anyone in the US also.
If the Time frame Xitended thru the Year of the Rat on the 25th I'd be much higher on this prospect.
